The 408th episode of Replay concludes Replay Civil War, featuring...
Elise Favis vs Suriel Vazquez, playing PocketBike Racer - winner: Elise
Kimberley Wallace vs Jeff Marchiafava, playing Skate 2 - winner: Jeff

With Jeff Marchiafava's victory, the last remaining player on Team Good is eliminated, meaning victory for Team Evil! However, one final battle is in order, to determine whose game gets Super Replayed (if the world happens to not end for some reason). The final battle:
Matt Bertz vs Jeff Marchiafava vs Andrew Reiner vs Elise Favis, playing Mario Party 4 - winner: Reiner
With Reiner's victory, he decides to let the GI community contribute ideas for his Super Replay, on the "I Watched the Entire Overblood Super Replay" group on Facebook.

In the final moments of the episode, the Replay Machine attempts to destroy the world, but is destroyed by Beanie Ben using a secret trick he learned from the Replay Machine in the future. The world is saved!

In this episode, Kyle gets Javy and Ben Reeves to help destroy the Replay Machine before the Replay Civil War can take place. They are unsuccessful, so they agree to a competition. Looks like next week, the Replay Civil War is happening - an epic battle of good vs evil in various gaming challenges...
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Jeff Marchiafava and Joe Juba.
Resident Evil 3: Nemesis is the title game for the 401st episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Battle Arena Toshinden.
In this episode, Reiner builds his army for the Replay Civil War. He manages to get Elise and Tack on the side of evil by possessing them, and recruits Wacky Reeves with a convincing flier.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features special guests Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Gamespot's Mike Mahardy.
Project Altered Beast is the title game for the 400th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Traysia.

In this episode, occurring at the same time as the events of the previous episode, Kyle overhears Reiner talking to the Replay Machine, and starts building up an opposing army to take down the Machine. He manages to recruit Javy, the Threeves, and Jeff Cork.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Jeff Cork and Dan Tack.
Battlefield: Bad Company is the title game for the 399th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features 3 Ninjas Kick Back.

In this episode, the Replay Machine (taking the form of OverBlood's Raz Karcy) informs Reiner that the Super Replay Showdown will be happening in a few weeks. The Machine feeds on anger and frustration, and the Showdown will provide the final nourishment the Machine needs. It asks Reiner to make sure whoever wins is on their side, and Reiner promises to build an army.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Joe Juba.
Super Mario Land is the title game for the 398th episode of Replay. The second segment for this episode is an installment of RePorted featuring Rune Caster.

In this episode, Dan Tack is finally rescued from Illusion of Gaia (where he was trapped as a character in the game). Joe Juba blows on the cartridge and frees him, but the crew instantly regrets it as they remember how annoying Dan is.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Joe Juba.
Jurassic Park: Operation Genesis is the title game for the 397th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Jurassic Park III: Park Builder.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Ben Hanson.
Turok is the title game for the 396th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Wolfchild.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Jeff Akervik.
Contra: Shattered Soldier is the title game for the 395th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulettes for this episode feature Vice: Project Doom and Illusion of Gaia.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Ben Reeves and Kyle Hilliard.

This episode starts with a calibration of the Replay Machine. Andrew Reiner takes us through the etymology of the phrase "easy as pie". The debate over the ease of which pie is eaten takes up the majority of the first segment and leads to the creation of the counter-phrase "hard as pudding".

After a brief look at Vice: Project Doom the crew switches to Illusion of Gaia. Dan Tack, previously stuck in Stuart Little, has become a profanity laced character within the game. After begging for help and shilling his Twitch channel he is thrown into prison. Due to time concerns, or perhaps not caring about Dan all that much, he is not rescued and the episode ends on a cliffhanger.

description: The 392nd episode of Replay is a Tween Television Extravaganza, featuring Cory in the House for Nintendo DS, Drake and Josh: Talent Showdown for Nintendo DS, Unfabulous for Game Boy Advance, Sabrina the Teenage Witch: Potion Commotion for Game Boy Advance, and Double Dare for NES.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Javy Gwaltney and Kyle Hilliard.

In this episode, Leo Vader reveals to Weenie Ben that his brother used to work at Game Informer seven years ago, and was mysteriously killed. Leo pretended to like video games so he could get a job at GI and investigate his brother's death. He believes the Replay Machine is behind the murder. On an unrelated (?) note, Beanie Ben reveals that he is responsible for preventing the apocalypse.
Devil May Cry 3 is the title game for the 391st episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Pitball.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Jeff Marchiafava and Joe Juba.

In this episode, the Replay Machine possesses the bodies of Andrew Reiner, Jeff Marchiafava, and Joe Juba. At the end of the episode, the Replay Machine takes the form of Raz Karcy (from Overblood) and tells them to kill Beanie Ben (the tiny one of the Threeves).
Revelations: Persona is the title game for the 390th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Laura (the Game Boy Color version of Laura's Happy Adventures).
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Ben Reeves and Joe Juba.
In this episode, Leo investigates the strange happenings in the GI office. He discovers the three Ben Reeveses, one of whom is now tiny. He captures the tiny one under a cup.
Crash: Mind Over Mutant is the title game for the 389th episode of Replay. The second segment this week is a Stress Test, with Joe playing the The High Road level of Crash Bandicoot.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Joe Juba.

In this episode, Ben Reeves and his two doppelgangers finally make it back to the GI office, only to discover they are ten years in the future, and the "Replay Civil War" has destroyed civilization. The Reeveses decide to play through every game in The Game Informer Vault, in alphabetical order, starting with Aaahh!!! Real Monsters.

By the end of the episode, they complete every game, and the Replay Machine grants them one wish. They wish to return to their original timeline, and their wish is granted. The three become one again, and everything is back to normal... for now. Reeves is humanity's only hope - the only one that can prevent the Replay Civil War.
Metal Slug 2 is the title game for the 388th episode of Replay. This is technically an unofficial Super Replay, as the game is completed in this episode.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard and Suriel Vazquez.

description: Assassin's Creed is the title game for the 385th episode and Season 4 premiere of Replay. Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and Joe Juba start off the season with the 4th chair remaining missing. The episode starts with the crew talking over the tutorial about their views on the series as a whole. After a jump cut and a few minutes with the game Reiner tells us of the early history of the franchise as it was nearly a Prince of Persia game. New to Replay we see in-episode cuts to other games, this time a prototype of the Price of Persia: Assassins.
In a brief middle segment Ben Reeves appears lost in a wooded area. While attempting to eat sticks he stumbles upon some salad-flavored leaves he uses for sustenance.

Stephen King's magnum opus The Adventures Of Tom Sawyer for the Nintendo Entertainment System is featured for this episode's roulette. The game was mentioned as being a Super Replay candidate just under 46 minutes into this season; a new record for the series.

God of War is the title game for the 384th episode and Season 3 finale of Replay. It is one of the few games given a Perfect 10. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Stuart Little: Big Photo Adventure.
The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard, Joe Juba, and Dan Tack.

In the final moments of the episode, Dan Tack foolishly utters the phrase "Dan Stamp!" and unleashes chaos upon the world. Former GI editors Tim Turi and Dan Ryckert make guest appearances as we start to see the true consequences of the Dan Stamp. The episode ends with the loss of the fourth chair (and Dan Tack).

Clearly the show cannot go on without the fourth chair, so Replay is over forever... or is it? We find out that Dan Tack is trapped inside Stuart Little: Big Photo Adventure. The story of Replay will continue on June 2 with Season 4.

The host for this episode is Andrew Reiner and features Kyle Hilliard, Jeff Cork, and Ben Reeves.

Mario Party 2 is the title game for the two hundred and thirty-second episode of Replay. Keeping with the tradition of every leading Mario Party Replay, there is no second segment to this episode. It aired on May 31, 2014.
Andrew Reiner is the host and is playing the game alongside Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Joe Juba. Jeff Cork sits in as a spectator and a manager for Dan.
trivia: This episode marks the last appearance of Dan Ryckert, the father of Replay, as a Game Informer editor. He announced the news the day before the episode aired, on May 30. After the episode, there is a tribute video that includes many clips of Dan over the years. Other members such as Ben Hanson and Jeff Cork sing in the chorus of a song about Dan prepared for the video, while Tim Turi provides the leading vocals.
As a result, Dan's last aired footage as a Game Informer employee is of him, hungover, throwing up into a toilet and giving the camera a dirty look.
In the week between the Replay: Blood Omen 2 episode and this one, Andrew Reiner mentioned off-hand that he was starting to plan Season 3 of Replay.

To date, the Game Informer has played Mario Party, Mario Party 2, and Mario Party 3 as main Replay segments. Mario Party 6 was the surprise Replay Roulette on the Replay Holiday Special 2013 special episode.

description: Second Sight is the title game of the one hundred eighty-sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Worms Armageddon.
The host of this episode is Joe Juba and features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Kim Wallace. Tim plays the featured game and everyone plays the Roulette.
notes: Reiner introduced the Roulette as being a new segment where competitive games are played among the host and featured guests.
This is another instance of the featured game being on a different console than the Roulette game. In this case Second Sight is on PlayStation 2 while Worms Armageddon is on PlayStation.
The tutorial of Second Sight was skipped in favor of starting the main part of the game. Most of the time Replays begin with the beginning of a game, tutorial and all.
Joe reviewed Second Sight in the September 2004 issue of Game Informer and gave the game an 8.5 out of 10.
"You won’t find as many staggeringly awesome moments as Psi-Ops, but it is certainly an inventive and unique stealth game in its own right."[1]
Reiner provided the "Second Opinion" review and scored it 7.5 out of 10.
"All told, however, Second Sight is the very definition of mediocrity."[1]

description: The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse is the 112th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 25, 2012.

This episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Ben Hanson, and special guest Brent Weinbach, comedian and host of the Legacy Music Hour podcast, who also chose the game for this episode. During the episode, they discuss music and other Mickey Mouse games, as well as Tim and Brent sharing a moment in the Vault. Ben Hanson does an impressive Mickey Mouse impersonation. Brent constantly tells the Replay team that he wishes he had more time to show them level 3 or 5.

The episode's second segment is Reported, in which the crew plays Rhythm Heaven, known as Rhythm Tengoku in Japan, for the GBA. According to Ben Hanson, Rhythm Heaven is not actually in the Game Informer vault, the copy of Rhythm Heaven that the crew plays is his personal copy which he imported.
notes: According to Brent, a major reason why he chose Magical Quest for this episode is because he is a huge fan of this game's soundtrack. Also, it's same composer for Breath of Fire.
Hanson learned "left" and "right" in Japanese from a particular mini-game in Rhythm Heaven.

description: 50 Cent: Bulletproof is the 111th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 18th, 2012.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Tim Turi (on controls), Kyle Hilliard, and special guest Haydn Dalton, lead designer of Darksiders II at Vigil Games.

The episode's second segment is the debut of Developer Pick, in which the developer who is the guest of the episode chooses a game to play. Haydn Dalton chooses Venom/Spider-Man: Separation Anxiety, which he and Tim play co-op.
notes: 50 Cent: Bulletproof was chosen for this replay because Haydn Dalton worked on the game before he worked on Darksiders and Darksiders II. He also worked on Venom/Spider-Man: Separation Anxiety, which is why he chose the game for the Developer Pick segment.

description: In this episode, the team consists of Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Tim Turi. They acknowledge their reduced number, due to Dan's mysterious disappearance coinciding with his father's appearance.

The episode starts with each of the team relating their experience with the game. Tim Turi has none, Andrew Reiner can faintly remember enjoying it, and Ben Reeves also has negligible experience. Reiner recalls especially enjoying the humor, and Tim appreciates the the Ghosts 'n' Ghoulies look of the game. Tim ponders if Sir Dan is a joke, as it reminds him of Iron Maiden's mascot.Tim gets annoyed with the camera, and Reiner digs up the other projects of the team behind MediEvil which are mostly ports of popular console game to handehelds(LBP for PSP, Killzone for Vita, etc.). As they backtrack for a Chalice, Reiner recalls a wrestling/gambling competition where Dan kept track of stats in crayon. Sir Dan gains access to the Hall of Heroes, and acquires a crossbow from an old subordinate. He contiunes to Cemetary Hill, where Princess Leia tries to kill him with boulders. Tim muses on the inconsistency of the zombie speed, and Reeves ptiches the idea for Jaoquin Dead, a spin-off of Walking Dead, starring Joaquin Pheonix. Sir Dan defeats the onslaught of boulders, and the gargoyles commit suicide in shame. Reeves says that is the same thing all editors must do if an article is not in on time, and is probably what happened to Dan. Tim says he was biting down on a Waluigi sandwich and accidentally activated his fake tooth with a cyanide pill and died. They explore a labrynth and encounter a harrowing stained-glass golem. After a tense fight, Tim defeats the golem.

They begin the Roulette, which is Juggernaut, a game that begins with evil Blood Moons, evil clown clocks, and evil dolls. A clingy boyfriend wants to talk to his girlfriend shapes the premise. Tim mocks the slow text of the Myst-style game, as an exorcist tells the clingy boyfriend that his girlfriend has had her soul stolen by an evil force. He must exorcise from within what is left of her soul. He enters a blood bag lit world, but unfortunately has no time to blood fish. He talks to Zorro, then steals his watch and searches for paintings. After a few more puzzles to no avail, the team ends the Replay.
quotes: Reeves: "This doesn't seem right at all!" Tim: "Turn to the right, and leave!"
Tim: "It's-the-doll-Sarah-loves."

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle

description: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle is the 109th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 7th, 2012. This episode's second segment is a Replay Roulette of the game Kid Chameleon.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Bryan Vore, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar, with Jason Oestreicher on video and technical duties (with occasional commentary).
alex_kidd.27s_antics: Alex explores a town, prairie, underwater level and a desert. Despite amusing animations, a carefree attitude, oddly proportioned fists, and a motorcycle Alex finds progress difficult and eventually succumbs from the combined efforts of a bounce block and a mummy.
replay_roulette: The Roulette episode is Kid Chameleon, which opens with Reiner apologizing for the absence of Replay 2037 and Dan rejoicing it. They immediately make fun of Kid Chameleon's appearance, and Bryan Vore shares a story of how a kid he went to high school with was the inspiration for Kid Chameleon(the kid's father was the box artist). Bryan murders mecha-gorillas with a samurai sword, and Reiner relates how he beat Chikan, a notoriously bad game. They reach the second level, where Bryan turns into a Rhino and fights Gish. They complete the level and play through a little of the next before ending the Roulette.

description: SSX Tricky is the featured game in the 99th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Sentient, which received an enthusiastic response from the Replay fanbase and was highly hyped to be an upcoming Super Replay. However, comments made during the 17th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay have casted doubt on the future status of Sentient as a Super Replay.
The episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Phil Kollar, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert.
The Hobbit is the featured game in the 98th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Scaler.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar, and features Jeff Cork, Tim Turi, and Andrew Reiner.

Rayman is the featured game in the 97th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Top Gun: Fire at Will. Rayman was chosen as a Replay candidate to coincide with the recent release of Rayman Origins, a favorite among Game Informer Editors.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Joe Juba on controls, Dan Ryckert on controls for the Roulette, and Ben Hanson as both guest and video editor for this episode.
rayman: Ben Hanson, a big fan of Rayman, gushes about this game the entire time, while Dan is skeptical. The game slowly impresses gameplay wise, but the whole crew is astounded by the colorful visuals. Joe is able to play well, making a fair amount of progress. Because Dan and Joe both appear on this episode, hijinks ensue. After Dan mentions Mario Party after Reiner explicitly tells him not to, he gives Joe free reign to slap Dan, something Joe does happily.
top_gun:_fire_at_will: The crew watches the lengthy opening scene that shows off the full motion video. After another scene, that actually includes Mr. Strickland from Back to the Future, the mission objective is shown. The whole crew laughs hysterically at "Avoid being killed by the ever-deadly ground", especially Joe. Not much happens, except everyone complimenting Top Gun (the movie), and Dan failing to avoid the "ever-deadly" ground.
quotes: "This is turning into the Howard Stern show," -Ben Hanson, after Joe slapped Dan.

description: Max Payne is the featured game in the 95th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Metal Arms: Glitch in the System.

Max Payne was chosen as a Replay shortly after Rockstar Games showed off Max Payne 3 at the Game Informer offices. This episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard (on controls), and Jim Reilly in his first Replay appearance.
notes: Tim describes himself as a "huge fan" of the Max Payne franchise in this episode. He describes the Max Payne theme as "within my top ten favorite video game songs of all time" and mentions having seen the Max Payne feature film in theaters, though he admits it is a "terrible" movie.

description: X-COM: UFO Defense is the featured game in the 94th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Audiosurf.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar, and features Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Jason Oestreicher.
in_this_episode: The episode begins with Phil butchering the pronunciation of Jason's last name. He corrects him, and then builds a GI Tower in Africa. As Jason explains the management aspect, Phil wonder if it will be present in 2K's FPS reimagining and Reiner confirms that it is. They research Laser Pistols, and deploy fighters after an alien ship. It out runs them twice, then lands. They outfit their crack squad of GI trained soldiers and exit the dropship to defeat the alien menace. They immediately lose a soldier, and suspect of the aliens of laughing at them and high-fiving in the fog of war. They lose another soldier once the alien's turn starts, much to Reiner's amusement. The recruits have horrible aim, unable to kill an alien just a few paces in front of them. Another soldier drops on the alien's turn, and on Jason's a soldier goes insane and finally manages to kill something. Reeves sprinkles his non-sequiter "street comedy" throughout the banter. Another soldier dies. Jason's mini-cannon fails to knock down an brick wall, much to his tactical disadvantage. They discuss the movie Blank Check and Reeves suggests throwing an alien at an alien. Another soldier dies. Phil tries to end it there, but Jason curtly tells him that he is not finished and continues with the game to kill another alien at close range. Phil then moves to Replay Roulette.
Replay Roulette is Audiosurf, and Jason plays a few songs from the Splatterhouse and Bastion OST before ending the episode.
quotes: Ben: "We'll just pretend we got them all, like the government."
Ben: "Smear yourself with alien blood and disguise yourself as an alien."

Super Mario 64 is the featured game in the 91st episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Mario Kart 64.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Phil Kollar, Dan Ryckert, and Tim Turi. Dan and Tim play the featured game while all four play the Roulette.
notes: Despite claims made during the episode, this is not the one hundredth Replay, but the ninety-first. For this to be considered Replay 100, one would need to count all eight Super Replays released prior to this episode, plus the one-off Super Readplay gag. The actual one hundredth episode is Replay: Joe & Mac 2: Lost in the Tropics.

Dan's Bowser run was faster than Tim's by 1:42; Tim took 1:58 to reach Bowser plus another 1:27 to defeat him, and Dan took 1:19 (including the death run) to reach him and only 18 seconds to kill him. Note that Bowser is considered defeated as soon as he hits the bomb.

description: Quest 64 is the featured game in the 89th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Hybrid Heaven.

This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Tim Turi. Tim plays both games. This is one of the few episodes where the Roulette lasts longer than the main Replay.
notes: Both games feature dialog without voice-overs, so Tim makes up his own out loud. While everyone else is amused, Dan shows his disliking to them. Tim dies in Quest 64 due to running out of freshbread.

When they start Hybrid Heaven, they find that no one knows who picked out the game, and then claim it might be a sign for a Super Replay. One of the characters, named Johnny, is shown walking around naked in his apartment (no M-rated parts showing) in the opening cutscene which freaks Dan out and becomes an onrunning joke during the Roulette. They also laugh out loud whenever the main character Diaz goes into a rather suggestive looking crawl. While Dan doesn't like the bland enviorment of the game, he and the others get interested with Diaz shooting Johnny, the strange combat system, and the RPG elements. They end saying they'll consider whether or not Hybrid Heaven will be a Super Replay.

description: Luigi's Mansion is the title game for the sixty-second episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on The Replay Roulette is WarioWare, Inc.: Mega Party Game$!

This episode is hosted by Tim Turi, and stars Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and first-time guest Sean Lowery. It is ironic that this was Sean's first appearance, as it was also his last. To commerate his leaving, he guested on a game he enjoyed. Dan and Tim had never played the game before, and were excited to try it out. For the main game, Tim was at the controls.

Starting from the beginning, Tim has some difficulty with the strange control style. Eventually he gets the hang of it, and progresses into the mansion. The whole crew is charmed by Luigi's quirkiness, immediately enjoying the game's humor.
The game was revisted as a Super Replay later on.

Ape Escape is the title game of the fifty-sixth episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 12, 2011.

This episode is hosted by Tim Turi (on controls) and features Dan Ryckert and Andrew Reiner. The Replay Roulette is Martian Gothic: Unification, the last of four nominations for a future Super Replay after Countdown Vampires (Replay 53), Dracula: The Resurrection (Replay 54), and Galerians (Replay 55). After the Game Informer community voted, Galerians became Super Replay 7. Martian Gothic received about 20% of the vote.
notes: Reiner talks about his Star Wars themed wedding, complete with lightsabers and a Death Star cake. His wife (also a Star Wars fan) organized it as a surprise to him.

Dan: "Monkey in the Water is my favorite Elton John album... That's an obscure Elton John reference, no one's gonna get that."
Tim: "Have you read Monkey Profiles? It's a really... It's a– uh, Chuck Palahniuk book. Really, really, really disturbing. Monkey Profiles."
credit_cookie: Audio clip of Tim's (erotic?) Mario emotes from earlier in the Replay plays over a picture of a frightening, ultra-realistic Mario head.

Red Dead Revolver is the name of the 51st episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on January 8, 2011.
The episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner and Phil Kollar.

Aside from stating this game was the spiritual inspriation for the later Rockstar game, Red Dead Redemption, the gang actually doesn't talk much about the title and instead focuses on Dan saying comical things.

Dan approached the game believing he had never played it before and was excited to see what had inspired one of his favorite games in the form of Red Dead Redemption. However, not 15 seconds into the first level, Dan realizes he HAS played the game before, though not much of it. He then remembers that maybe it was the western shooter, Gun, that he didn't play very much of either. But as Dan recalls the boss fight he was in that made him quit playing, he's told by Reiner that the fight Dan was describing, was indeed the final boss, and Dan had incidentally quit the game, right before beating it.
The only time the gang really focuses on the game itself is when Dan starts kicking guys in the "nuts," foreshadowing the Half-life Super Replay,
The Replay Roulette for this episode is BMX XXX.

description: Mike Tyson's Punch-Out!! is the title game of the forty-sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Amagon.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Bryan Vore. All four play the main game while Dan plays the Roulette.
notes: Dan was so invested in Punch-Out!! that he was unable to refrain from twitching while playing and watching others play. This amused Reiner so much that he had a camera brought into the Replay room to catch it on video.
Dan considers Mike Tyson's Punch-Out!! one of his ten favorite games of all time, and says it may be his favorite NES game.

Reiner's poll of the GI staff found that only six of them claim to have defeated Mike Tyson: Reiner, Andy McNamara, Jeff Cork, Matt Miller, Matt Bertz, and Jeff Akervik. On the January 26, 2012 episode of The Game Informer Show, Joe and Dan noted that they still have not defeated Tyson.

Dan: "I am sweating, by the way."

Revolution X is the name of the 28th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer Website on July 31, 2010.

Revolution X is one of the most famous episodes of Replay as a result of its Roulette, OverBlood, which would become one of the most popular and well-regarded Super Replays on the site. The Revolution X episode of Replay was selected by the Replay crew as their favorite episode of Replay not only for being the "birthplace of OverBlood" but for being a generally "fantastic" episode lampooning a "ridiculous" game.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Replay regulars Andrew Reiner and Tim Turi (alternating on controls) as well as guest Matt Helgeson.

trivia: Matt Helgeson was on call during this episode. The reason was that he was waiting to hear from his wife, who was expected to go into labor any day.

Devil May Cry is the featured game in this episode of Replay. Dan Ryckert takes the role as the host, with Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba as guests.

The episode starts with Mission 2 of Devil May Cry, with Joe at the controls. Most of the episode, Reiner berates Dan's skills at Devil May Cry, mocking him having trouble on the first mission. Joe joins in, and the two ridicule Dan's practice of using the guns over any other weapon. Together, Joe is able to complete the mission, and the next mission.

For the Roulette, they play Fugitive Hunter: War on Terror. Tim Turi is at the controls, and has difficulty controlling the game. After a brief first-person-shooter level, the game switches to a 2D fighter. This change up, and the game's poor fighting method proves to be hilarious to the crew. After capturing one terrorist in the game, they end the episode.
credits_cookies: When Dan was giving the outro, he slurred "War on Terror" with the word "Here" and the rest of the crew thought he said "War on Terrier". Dan even repeats the phrase a couple of times, being admitting to maybe have saying "Terrier". If you listen very closely, you should be able to hear the sentence.

description: Final Fight: Streetwise is the featured game in the 17th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Rune: Viking Warlord.
This episode is hosted by Bryan Vore, and features Jeff Cork, Joe Juba, and Dan Ryckert.

Super Mario SunshineIn this episode, the Replay Crew plays Super Mario Sunshine for the Nintendo GameCube. The game is set in a resort island known as Delfino Island. Mario must clear his name by cleaning up the polution Shadow Mario has created.

As they pass the controller around, the crew also tries to figure out why Super Mario Sunshine was not as well recieved as the other 3-D Mario games. This is the first time Riener has seen Dan "be good with video games." Throughout the Mario Sunshine segment, Tim, Dan, and Reiner also list things Phil hates, including ice cream, Terminator 2, and water slides.
The segment ends with Tim grasping a Shine Sprite, and Phil muttering under his breath, "I still hate it."
WWE Crush Hour

A game seemingly made for Dan Ryckert, WWE Crush Hour is a demolition derby style game made for the Playstation 2 and Nintendo GameCube. Vince McMahon has gained control of every television network, filling them up with shows starring professional wrestlers. His latest creation, Crush Hour pits wrestlers against each other in vehicles filled with weapons to annihilate the competition. The objective is to gain as many points as possible by destroying the other cars.
The crew passes the controller between Dan and Tim as they tried to win a match. The roullette ends with a loss, not that Tim minds.
post_credits_cookie: Dan edits Phil's audioclips to repeatedly say, "I hate it. I don't hate it. I hate it. I don't hate it."
trivia: Dan rates Super Mario Sunshine above The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker
Phil Kollar addresses that Super Mario Galaxy is the only 3-D Mario game he likes (as of the recording date).
This is the first time a Mario game has been shown on an episode of Replay.
This is also the most recent Mario game that has been featured on an episode of Replay or Super Replay.

notes: This Replay is one of the few that does not follow the standard "One host, three guests" format. No particular reason is given.
quotes: Spyro the Dragon
Reiner: "You go with, like, Jason Statham or something like that. You don't pick Elijah Wood when to try to mature something."
Future Cop LAPD
Tim: "Welcome to FMV's."
Tim: "It looks like we're looking at an...Oh, boy."
Reiner: "Is this, like, a Star Trek convention? Look at all these outfits."
Tim: "I'll tell ya, this game belongs in the trash can."

description: Blaster Master is the tenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Disaster Report.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Matt Miller, Andrew Reiner, and Jeff Marchiafava. Phil, Reiner, and Matt play the featured game, while Reiner and Matt play the Roulette.
notes: This is an instance where the featured game and the Roulette are from two different consoles. Blaster Master is an NES title, whereas Disaster Report is on the Playstation 2.
Jeff is given the nickname "The Fav" in this episode, much to his annoyance.
Phil Kollar suggests a read through of the novelization of Blaster Master. Something similar does occur in "Super Readplay: Gears of War: Anvil Gate".
quotes: Blaster Master
Reiner: "That almost gave me a seizure. That was some violent shaking."
Phil: "Also, the end of the game gives you a screen that says 'Very Thanks'."
Reiner: "It'd be like mutant Old Yeller."
Marchiafava:" The reason is I lost my radioactive frog when I was a child."
Disaster Report
Phil: "I got the box here, on the back is says "Escape the fury of nature". That's what you get to do right now."
Matt: "Have you ever been to Airport Island, Phil? There's a lot of planes."
Matt: "That is a steep descent. There's a lot of screaming people aboard that plane right now."
Reiner: "I'm going to hit the button. I can't hit the button."
Reiner: "There's my ticket outta here. This might be a short game."
credit_cookie: Phil telling Matt the real reason he was invited to the Replay.

description: Mortal Kombat Mythologies: Sub-Zero is the title game of the ninth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Wu-Tang: Shaolin Style.

This episode is notable for having a different cast of editors for the featured game and the Roulette. The main game is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Ben Reeves, Bryan Vore, and Tim Turi. Everyone takes turns playing the featured game.
The Roulette is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Matt Helgeson, Annette Gonzalez, and Tim Turi. Everyone gets a chance to play the Roulette.
notes: This is the first appearance of Annette Gonzalez.
This is one of the few Replays where the featured game is neither liked nor really played by any of the crew as children.
Matt Helgeson and Annette Gonzalez are self-proclaimed Wu-Tang Clan fans.

This is the start of long tradition of the Replay crew asking for audience participation for a given project. This would later lead to a number of competitions for t-shirt designs after Super Replays.
quotes: Mortal Kombat: Mythologies: Sub Zero
Bryan: "Good in concept, terrible in execution."
Ben: "Oh my gosh - Scorpion."
Tim: "Every time you get an item some guy just comes and just-", Ben: "Son of a b****!" as he is attacked by another enemy.
Tim: "Yeah, cool down!" after firing a freeze projectile.
Tim: "Sorry, old friend." while crouching over Scorpion's corpse.
Dan: "I think we are about to be treated to our first cut scene, which is just awesome."
Dan: "Notice that Sub-Zero only stands in action figure poses."
Ben: "I think I saw a Teletubbies episode that was more compelling than this."
Tim: "Betry nothing. Don't smirk."
Tim: "He clearly cannot control his legs anymore."
Tim: "This looks like something from Legends of the Hidden Temple."
Wu-Tang: Shaolin Style
Annette: "Is he barking?"
Matt: "I saw them live and Ghostface was actually texting on stage between
his verses on his Blackberry."
Matt: "We should just have a Wu Tang reminiscing podcast."
Tim: "Did they teleport on the stage, too?"
Matt: "Is nuts a bad word?"
credit_cookie: Outtake of Matt rapping while Dan tries to introduce the Roulette; gameplay from MKM of Sub-Zero floating.

description: ActRaiser is the title of the eighth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Incredible Crisis.

This episode is notable for having a two different cast of editors playing the featured game and the Roulette. The main game his hosted by Bryan Vore and features Joe Juba, Tim Turi, and Phil Kollar. Bryan Vore plays the feature game.
A new crew is brought in for the Roulette with Phil Kollar hosting, and features Andrew Reiner, Matt Miller, and Jeff Marchiafava. Reiner and Jeff trade the controller while playing.
notes: This is an instance in Replay where the featured video game and the Roulette are from two different consoles. ActRaiser is an SNES title, whereas Incredible Crisis is on the Playstation.
This episode is the debut of Bryan Vore, Matt Miller and Jeff Marchiafava on Replay.
Phil had never played the featured game, and Joe and Bryan had extensive childhood memories with it. Tim had played it later on the Virtual Console.
The silent Roulette intro happens again in this episode before Incredible Crisis.
quotes: ActRaiser
Phil: "Your name is Sir God."
Tim: "That tree seems like he's confused."
Tim: "It's convenient that they all hang on to each other like Monkeys in a Barrel, though, it really makes the bats' jobs a lot easier."
Phil: "It should be noted that it's a pretty common theological belief that the more followers a god has, the more he levels up."
Bryan: "Maybe one of the firsts butts in a game." Phil: "Very Progressive."
Bryan: "Yet again, lightning is the solution to everything in this level."
Joe: "Everyone knows wheat is an upgrade to corn."
Joe: "Did you do that whole set-up just for the ActRaisenets joke?"
Incredible Crisis
Matt: "I feel confident I've never played this game."
Jeff: "Dance Fever." Reiner: "That's how my day starts."
Jeff: "Especially Tim Turi in the red dress."
Phil: "Reiner is now dancing." Reiner: "If it goes any faster I might have to take off my pants."
Reiner: "Don't lose your job on Incredible Crisis.

description: Turok: Dinosaur Hunter is the title of the seventh episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Tonic Trouble.

This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Ben Reeves. Reiner plays the featured game, passing the controller to Dan midway through. Ben begins playing the Roulette, but Tim takes the controller away halfway through.
notes: Ben is given the nickname "AVP" in this episode, starting a tradition of sorts of giving random nicknames to guests. Andrew also purposely mispronounces Dan's last name as "Reinhart".
Reiner reviewed Turok: Dinosaur Hunter in the March 1997 issue of Game Informer. He gave the game a 9.5 out of 10.
"Turok is a sure fire hit in every category, and a must have for all N64 owners, game addicts, and beginners who want to see the most impressive graphics display on the planet."[1]
quotes: Turok
Tim: "I'd like to point out that you, uh, let that monkey get off scot-free."
Tim: "Reiner, I need you to make an explicit promise that you're going to kill any remaining wildlife."
Dan: "...it's 20 feet, and then fog."
Tim: "I'd have to make an argument for "Jumpin' Jack Flash" or whatever the [bleep] that bunny game was.
Reiner: "I remember buying this game, and when it came out, I think it was 79 dollars."
Tim: "Campaigner's a dumb name for an enemy."
Ben: "Dino dancin' on the stairs."
Tonic Trouble
Dan: "It seems like so many companies were just stretching for mascots back then, with all these platformers."
Tim: "It worked for Superman 64 so let's just do it right here."
Tim: "I'm going to go ahead and grab the controller and see if you're really that inept."
Tim: "Why does a platformer need this much dialogue?"
Tim: "If something entertaining doesn't happen within the next ten seconds, we're going to end this."
Ben: "You hate this don't you?"
references: ↑ Reiner, Andrew. "Setting a New Standard For First-Person Gaming." GameInformer.com Mar. 1997. Original retrieved 1997-10-21.

description: Apocalypse is the title game of the sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is The Simpsons Wrestling.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Nick Ahrens, Andrew Reiner, and Tim Turi. Nick plays the main game while all four play the Roulette.
notes: Both Nick and Dan owned The Simpson's Wrestling as children, and both hated it considerably.
The Roulette intro has an alternate sound this episode.
Reiner reviewed The Simpsons Wrestling in the June 2001 issue of Game Informer. He gave the game a 2 out of 10.
"The rest of the game is, and forever shall be, a major disappointment and one of the worst PS-X games to date."[1]
quotes: Apocalypse
Reiner: "Hey, wait. You guys are missing the cockroach drinking the blood, here."
Nick: "That's Bruce Willis if you punched him in the mouth repeatedly."
Tim: "They just showed you, you gotta shoot that. Or kick it!"
Nick: "This must be the beginning of rumble, too, because the controller has not stopped rumbling at all. It's just constantly moving."
Reiner: "When they made these bridges, they knew they were going to fall apart. Do you see the warnings they have on them?"
Nick: "Nice try, floor!"
Nick: "All the buttons seem to do the same thing."
Tim: "I can see the marketing campaign, "Did you like Metal Gear Solid? Did you like search lights? Armageddon!"
Nick: "If an inmate gets homing missiles it's just over."
The Simpsons Wrestling
Tim (before title screen): "I going to have to say that this involves... Arnold Schwarzenegger, and... southern rock."
Tim: "Whatever it is, I don't care if it's co-op, I'm going to win."
Tim: "Would you be comfortable saying that we're having fun right now?" Reiner: "No."
Nick: "That's like the grief move, just jump up and down on their head. Like in real wrestling. I'm not tal...I'm talking about Olympic wrestling."
Dan: "Round two of a wrestling match? That's not how that works."
Dan: "I had a lot more fun last week playing Mad Max. And I think I gave that a three."
Reiner: "It's a [bleep] out of 10."
references: ↑ Reiner, Andrew. "The Simpsons Wrestling." GameInformer.com. June 2001. Retrieved 2009-03-03. Wayback Machine. <http://web.archive.org/web/20090303155114/http://www.gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200106/R03.0804.1422.55863.htm>

description: DuckTales is the title of the fifth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Yo! Noid. Mad Max is played as a bonus Roulette game.

The episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Andrew Reiner. Tim plays the featured game, passing the controller to Reiner after one death. After getting stuck, they switch to DuckTales 2 which Tim plays. Dan plays both the Roulette and Bonus Roulette games.
notes: Phil and Dan are both huge fans of DuckTales, playing it extensively as children. Dan was unaware of the sequel.
This is the second episode with a silent Roulette intro. The first being Star Wars: Masters of Teräs Käsi.
The Roulette intro plays for both the regular Roulette and the Mad Max bonus Roulette.
DuckTales is the first NES game to be featured on Replay.
quotes: DuckTales
Phil: "Next time you're at a pond, throw the ducks some ice cream."
Tim: "Donald Duck was actually just a deadbeat father."
Reiner: "Is that your finger?! What is that? Is this rated M?"

Tim: "Fans of the DuckTales series know that, in that universe, the Duckberg universe, there actually is no god. So to associate Christianity with the Duck Tales, I think would be a gross misstep in continuity of the series."
DuckTales 2
Dan: "LaunchPad McQuack. That's the best name in cartoon history."
Tim: "Can you see Daisy really, you know, getting it on with Donald? It was, those kids are Launch Pad's."
Yo! Noid
Tim: "Did Domino's hire Elmer Fudds with harpoons to hunt down Yo Noid?
Dan: "Look how mayor is spelled. With an 'E'."
Mad Max
Tim: "Why is damage a hammer? Why is water a tea kettle? Why is food a marshmellow?"
Dan: "[This] game's bad."
credit_cookie: The NES console is having trouble starting up, and the crew is fiddling around trying to get it to start. Starts with Dan exclaiming, "That's a screen I'm use to seeing with the NES."

description: Star Wars: Masters of Teräs Käsi is the title game of the fourth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Jumping Flash!
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba, all of whom take turns playing the featured game while Tim plays the Roulette and later hands off to Joe.
notes: It is explained that Reiner and Joe are huge Star Wars fans, with Matt Bertz being the biggest.
No sound plays during the Roulette intro.
quotes: Star Wars: Masters of Teräs Käsi
Joe: "... it's like 'I have it, I'm gonna play it, and I'm gonna decide that I love it', so I did."
Tim: "The trick to bringing in diehard fans into a new game spin-off of a popular series is to create a new character that no one cares about."
Reiner: "Hadouken doesn't seem to be doing anything."
Tim: "That's just a boot to the face, Joe. Joe you did it again, Joe. Joe, I think you're hitting the wrong buttons."
Tim: "This time I will not let the wookie win. Right?"
Dan: "I'm just pistol whipping you."
Tim: "This guy plays like Thok."
Joe: "...the Tusken Raider's name is Hoar." Tim: "How do you spell that, Joe?"
Andrew: "Hold on, I found this stick in my back pocket. Let's see what it does."
Tim: "I believe it was space chess."
Tim: "The main Ewok, the leader of all the Ewoks, uh, is president Wicket. He rules with an iron fist."
Jumping Flash!
Dan: "Jetpoo?"
Dan: "The same developer made a game called Geograph Seal for the Sharp X68000." Tim: "I love that system."

description: Jaws Unleashed is the title game of the third episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Azurik: Rise of Perathia.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and Tim Turi. Andrew plays the featured game while Dan plays the Roulette, passing the controller to Tim midway through.
notes: Phil notes that Andrew is terrified of sharks, which Andrew readily agrees with.
This episode came in at number 5 of Game Informer's "Top Ten Episodes of Replay" feature.
Dan reviewed Jaws Unleashed during college for Lawrence.com and gave the game a 6.9 out of 10.
"Worth a rental at least for fans of the film or senseless destruction."[1]
Reiner also reviewed Jaws Unleashed, but for Game Informer. He gave the game a 4.75 out of 10.
"After this miserable showing, the only waters that Jaws will be patrolling are those of the great video game toilet."[2]
quotes: Jaws Unleashed
Tim: "That shark's name is Bruce, right?...from the movie ... ... Not that obscure piece of a trivia! His name is Bruce, I'm not asking anymore, I'm telling you his name is Bruce."

Dan: "Remember that trademark Jaws scene where he just ate all the license plates?" Tim: "Right, he got all 45 and then the 45th one was the end of the movie. If you actually stayed after the credits he got the other 5."
Phil: "Little known piece of Reiner trivia here, you are actually afraid of sharks."
Dan: "Did you see what that said, it said 'in oder'. O-D-E-R."
Andrew: "But this right here is, like, my living fear." Tim: "Turning into a shark car?"

Dan: "What happens if sharks ever evolve legs, and come to Minneapolis." Tim: "You have the same answer to the question 'What if spiders learn how to fly?' It's just one gun, one bullet. You know what to do."

Tim: "I think there's some beaches in Florida had to close down because, I think they had a shark that actually hit level cap. I think it was, yeah, level 80. That was a big problem because he unlocked lightning."
Tim: "2 Fast 2 Furious Unleashed: Jaws Edition Renegade."
Dan: "You shouldn't have wasted all your skill points on the 'Charm' ability."
Azurik: Rise of Perathia
Phil: "Break these vases." Tim: "Zelda clone."
Tim: "Their sound effect guy must have been on vacation."
Phil (to Tim): "You have this disdain in your voice for the way Dan plays video games."
Tim: "That looks cool. Alright, nevermind."
Phil: "This is going in the Vault and it's never getting taken out again."
trivia: Appaloosa Interactive, the developer of Jaws Unleashed, also developed the Ecco series for Sega. Ecco is famous for starring a dolphin as the main protagonist.[3]
Azurik: Rise of Perathia was featured on the cover of the May 2001 issue of Game Informer.

description: Bushido Blade is the title game of the second episode of Replay. This is the debut of the Replay Roulette, which featured NBA Live '96.

This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Phil Kollar, Jeff Cork, and Andrew Reiner. The crew takes turns playing the featured game, passing the controller on death. Phil and Reiner go head-to-head in the Roulette.
notes: This is the inaugural episode of Replay Roulette, where the host grabs a random game from The Vault and plays it after the feature game.

The host initially picked the Roulette game by being blindfolded and spun within the vault and choosing a game randomly, but this was soon changed to picking the game with some purpose, either because of it's similarities to the featured game, the host used to love/play the game as a child, or general curiosity about the game.
Several screens of The Vault are shown after the first segment before the Roulette is chosen.
quotes: Bushido Blade
Jeff (to Dan): "You really cannot do any worse."
Jeff: "I like the A.I. that hits you while you are down."
Phil: "Her weakness was her back, there needs to be a glowing, orange dot back there."
NBA Live '96
Phil: "I also don't know the rules of basketball, so that's going to severely hinder my performance."
Dan: "We have a thrilling four-to-nothing game going on."
Dan: "How are the controls?" Reiner: "Um...atrocious."
Reiner: "I think Shaq just killed someone on the other end of the floor."

description: "Twisted Metal 1–4" is the name of the inaugural episode of Replay. Unlike later installments, this episode focuses on a series/genre instead of a specific game, and has no Replay Roulette. The featured games are:
Twisted Metal
Twisted Metal 2
Twisted Metal III
Critical Depth
Rogue Trip: Vacation 2012
Twisted Metal 4
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Tim Turi, Nick Ahrens, and Andrew Reiner, all of whom take turns playing.
quotes: Reiner: "I kind of like wiener [action]."
credit_cookie: Reiner says, "I kind of like the wiener [action]."
